</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Due to the nature of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	percentage-of-completion
</FONT>
</FONT>
	accounting, changes in our cost of sales for both products and services are typically accompanied by changes in our net sales. The following
	discussion of material changes in our consolidated cost of sales for products and services should be read in tandem with the preceding discussion of changes in our consolidated net sales and our business segment results of operations. We have not
	identified any developing trends in cost of sales for products and services that would have a material impact on our future operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Product Costs
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Product costs increased approximately $5.5&nbsp;billion, or 18%, in 2016 as compared to 2015. The increase was
	primarily due to increased product costs of about $3.6&nbsp;billion at RMS and about $1.6&nbsp;billion at Aeronautics. The increase at RMS was primarily attributable to product costs generated by Sikorsky, which was acquired in the fourth quarter of
	2015. The increase at Aeronautics was primarily attributable to increased volume on aircraft production for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program and increased aircraft deliveries on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Product costs increased approximately $108&nbsp;million, or less
	than 1%, in 2015 as compared to 2014. Increased product costs of approximately $445&nbsp;million at RMS and about $180&nbsp;million at Aeronautics, were offset by decreases in product costs of approximately $325&nbsp;million at Space Systems and
	$195&nbsp;million at MFC. Increases in product costs at RMS were due primarily to the Sikorsky acquisition, including costs of Sikorsky products, intangible amortization and adjustments required
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	33
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	to account for the acquisition in the fourth quarter of 2015. Higher product costs at Aeronautics were attributable to the reasons stated above for higher product sales, as well as decreased risk
	retirements (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-22).
</FONT>
	The changes in product costs at Space Systems and MFC were attributable to the reasons stated above for higher product sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Service Costs
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Service
	costs increased approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion, or 25%, in 2016 compared to 2015, primarily due to increased service costs of about $670&nbsp;million at RMS and approximately $400&nbsp;million at Aeronautics. The increase at RMS was primarily
	attributable to service costs generated by Sikorsky, which was acquired in the fourth quarter of 2015. The increase at Aeronautics was primarily attributable to increased sustainment activities (primarily the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	the&nbsp;F-22
</FONT>
	programs).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Service
	costs increased approximately $640&nbsp;million, or 15%, in 2015 compared to 2014. Higher service costs of approximately $450&nbsp;million at Aeronautics and about $230&nbsp;million at Space Systems were due to the reasons stated above for higher
	service sales. These increases in service costs were partially offset by a decrease in service costs of about $80&nbsp;million at MFC due primarily to lower service costs on various air and missile defense programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Restructuring Charges
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 Actions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016, we recorded severance charges totaling approximately $80&nbsp;million related to our Aeronautics
	business segment. The charges consisted of severance costs associated with the planned elimination of certain positions through either voluntary or involuntary actions. Upon separation, terminated employees receive
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	severance payments primarily based on years of service, the majority of which are expected to be paid over the next several quarters. During 2016, we paid $70&nbsp;million in severance payments
	associated with these actions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 Actions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2015, we recorded severance charges totaling $82&nbsp;million, of which $67&nbsp;million related to our RMS business
	segment and $15&nbsp;million related to businesses that were reported in our former IS&amp;GS business prior to our fourth quarter 2015 program realignment. The charges consisted of severance costs associated with the planned elimination of certain
	positions through either voluntary or involuntary actions. Upon separation, terminated employees receive
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	severance payments primarily based on years of service, the majority of which are expected to
	be paid over the next several quarters. During 2016, we paid $64&nbsp;million in severance payments associated with these actions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with the Sikorsky acquisition, we assumed obligations related to certain restructuring actions committed to by
	Sikorsky in June 2015. Net of amounts we anticipate to recover through the pricing of our products and services to our customers, we incurred and paid $40&nbsp;million of costs in 2016 related to these actions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We expect to recover a substantial amount of the restructuring charges through the pricing of our products and services to the
	U.S. Government and other customers in future periods, with the impact included in the respective business segment&#146;s results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other
	Unallocated, Net
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other unallocated, net primarily includes the FAS/CAS pension adjustment as described in the
	Business Segment Results of Operations section below, stock-based compensation and other corporate costs. These items are not allocated to the business segments and, therefore, are excluded from the cost of sales for products and services. Other
	unallocated, net was $550&nbsp;million of income in 2016, compared to expense of $47&nbsp;million in 2015 and $96&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The fluctuation between each respective period was primarily attributable to the change in the FAS/CAS pension adjustment of
	$902&nbsp;million in 2016, $400&nbsp;million in 2015 and $317&nbsp;million in 2014, partially offset by fluctuations in other costs associated with various corporate items, none of which were individually significant. The changes in the FAS/CAS
	pension adjustment between the periods was primarily attributable to the increase in U.S. Government Cost Accounting Standards (CAS) pension cost due to the impact of phasing in CAS Harmonization. See &#147;Critical Accounting
	Policies&nbsp;&#150;Postretirement Benefit Plans&#148; discussion below for more information on our CAS pension cost.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As
	a result of the divestiture of the IS&amp;GS business, we retained all assets and obligations related to pension benefits earned by current and former IS&amp;GS business salaried employees through the closing of the Transaction. Pension costs were
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	34
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	historically allocated to and included in the results of operations of the IS&amp;GS business. In connection with the reclassification of the IS&amp;GS business as discontinued operations, we
	reclassified the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-service
</FONT>
	portion of net pension costs related to IS&amp;GS business salaried employee benefits (interest cost, actuarial gains and losses and expected return on plan assets) from cost of
	sales (and previously reported in the IS&amp;GS business&#146; operating profit) to other unallocated, net on our consolidated statements of earnings as corporate expenses because these costs will continue to be incurred by us subsequent to the
	Transaction. The service portion of net pension costs related to IS&amp;GS business salaried employees that transferred to Leidos continued to be included in the operating results of the IS&amp;GS business classified as discontinued operations
	because such costs will no longer be incurred by us subsequent to the Transaction. These net pension costs were $54&nbsp;million, $71&nbsp;million and $59&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with the divestiture of the IS&amp;GS business and reclassification of the IS&amp;GS business to discontinued
	operations for all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, certain corporate overhead costs incurred by us and previously allocated to the IS&amp;GS business were reclassified from the IS&amp;GS business results (which is
	recorded in net earnings from discontinued operations) to other unallocated, net in our consolidated statements of earnings. These overhead costs related to expenses for senior management, legal, human resources, finance, accounting, treasury, tax,
	information technology, communications, ethics and compliance, corporate employee benefits, incentives and stock-based compensation, shared services processing and administration and depreciation for corporate fixed assets, and were not directly
	attributable to the IS&amp;GS business. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 we reclassified $82&nbsp;million, $165&nbsp;million and $169&nbsp;million of corporate overhead costs to other unallocated, net.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We allocate certain corporate overhead costs and defined benefit pension costs to our business segments because under U.S.
	Government contracting regulations such costs are allowable in establishing prices for contracts with the U.S. Government. Although the corporate overhead costs and defined benefit pension costs that were historically allocated to and included in
	the operating results of the IS&amp;GS business have been reclassified to and included in the results of our continuing operations for financial reporting purposes, we will allocate similar costs incurred in future periods to our remaining business
	segments and expect to recover a substantial amount of these costs through the pricing of our products and services to the U.S. Government and other customers in future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Other Income, Net
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other income, net primarily includes our share of earnings or losses from equity method investees and gains or losses for
	acquisitions and divestitures. Other income, net in 2016 was $487&nbsp;million, compared to $220&nbsp;million in 2015 and $329&nbsp;million in 2014. The increase in 2016, compared to 2015, was primarily attributable to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	net gain of $104&nbsp;million associated with obtaining a controlling interest in AWE and approximately $120&nbsp;million of increased earnings generated by equity method investees as discussed in the
	&#147;Business Segment Results of Operations&#148; section below. Additionally, in 2015 we incurred a $90&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	impairment charge related to our decision in 2015 to divest our LMCFT business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The decrease in 2015, compared to 2014, was primarily due to a $90&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	impairment charge related to our decision in 2015 to divest our LMCFT business and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recoverable
</FONT>
	transaction costs of approximately $38&nbsp;million
	associated with the Sikorsky acquisition, partially offset by fluctuations in other various costs, none of which were individually significant. The asset impairment charge was partially offset by a net deferred tax benefit related to LMCFT of about
	$80&nbsp;million, which is recorded in income tax expense. Earnings from equity method investees in 2015 were comparable to 2014 (reflecting decreased earnings from equity method investees in our Space Systems business segment, offset by increased
	earnings from Sikorsky equity method investees).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Interest Expense
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest expense in 2016 was $663&nbsp;million, compared to $443&nbsp;million in 2015 and $340&nbsp;million in 2014. The
	increases in interest expense in 2016 and 2015 relate to debt we incurred to fund the acquisition of Sikorsky, and the issuance of notes in February of 2015 for general corporate purposes. See &#147;Capital Structure, Resources and Other&#148;
	included within &#147;Liquidity and Cash Flows&#148; discussion below and &#147;Note 10&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Debt&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for a discussion of our debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Operating
</FONT>
	Income, Net
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-operating
</FONT>
	income, net decreased $30&nbsp;million from 2015 to 2016 primarily
	due to a gain from the sale of an investment in 2015 which did not recur in 2016. Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-operating
</FONT>
	income, net increased $25&nbsp;million from 2014 to 2015 due to a gain from the sale of an investment in
	2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	35
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Income Tax Expense
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our effective income tax rate from continuing operations was 23.2% for 2016, 27.3% for 2015, and 30.4% for 2014. The rates for
	all periods benefited from tax deductions for U.S. manufacturing activities, deductions for dividends paid to our defined contribution plans with an employee stock ownership plan feature, and the U.S. research and development (R&amp;D) tax credit.
	The U.S. manufacturing deduction benefit for 2016, 2015, and 2014 reduced our effective tax rate by 2.4, 2.9, and 2.6 percentage points, respectively. The rate for 2016 also benefited from the nontaxable gain recorded in connection with the
	consolidation of AWE.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In addition, the rate for 2016 benefited from the additional tax benefits related to employee
	share-based payment awards, which are now recorded in earnings as income tax benefit or expense, effective with the adoption of an accounting standard update during the second quarter of 2016. As a result, we are required to report the impacts as
	though the accounting standard update had been adopted on January&nbsp;1, 2016. Accordingly, we recognized additional income tax benefits of $152&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, which reduced our effective income tax rate
	by 3.1 percentage points. The adjustment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 includes second, third, and fourth quarter impacts and the reclassification of income tax benefits of $104&nbsp;million originally recognized in additional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	paid-in
</FONT>
	capital in the first quarter of 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016, the R&amp;D tax credit reduced
	our effective tax rate by 2.2 percentage points. In December 2015, the R&amp;D tax credit was permanently extended and reinstated, retroactive to the beginning of 2015, which reduced our effective income tax rate by 1.6 percentage points. In 2014,
	the R&amp;D tax credit was temporarily reinstated for one year, retroactive to the beginning of 2014, which reduced our effective tax rate by 0.9 percentage point.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of a decision in 2015 to divest our LMCFT business in 2016, we recorded an asset impairment charge of
	approximately $90&nbsp;million. This charge was partially offset by a net deferred tax benefit of about $80&nbsp;million. The net impact of the resulting tax benefit reduced our effective income tax rate by 1.2 percentage points in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Future changes in tax law could significantly impact our provision for income taxes, the amount of taxes payable, and our
	deferred tax asset and liability balances. Recent proposals to lower the U.S. corporate income tax rate would require us to reduce our net deferred tax assets upon enactment of new tax legislation, with a corresponding material,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	increase in income tax expense, but our income tax expense and payments would be materially reduced in subsequent years. Our net deferred tax assets as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 were $6.6&nbsp;billion and $6.1&nbsp;billion, based on a 35% the Federal statutory income tax rate, and primarily relate to our postretirement benefit plans. If legislation reducing the Federal statutory income tax
	rate to 15% had been enacted at December&nbsp;31, 2016, our net deferred tax assets would have been reduced by $3.8&nbsp;billion and we would have recorded a corresponding
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	increase in income tax expense of $3.8&nbsp;billion. This additional expense would be less if the legislation phased in the tax rate reduction or if the final rate was higher than 15%. The amount of net
	deferred tax assets will change periodically based on several factors, including the measurement of our postretirement benefit plan obligations and actual cash contributions to our postretirement benefit plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net Earnings from Continuing Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We reported net earnings from continuing operations of $3.8&nbsp;billion ($12.38 per share) in 2016, $3.1&nbsp;billion ($9.93
	per share) in 2015 and $3.3&nbsp;billion ($10.09 per share) in 2014. Both net earnings and earnings per share from continuing operations were affected by the factors mentioned above. Earnings per share also benefited from a net decrease of
	approximately 14&nbsp;million common shares outstanding from December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31, 2016 and approximately 11&nbsp;million common shares outstanding from December&nbsp;31, 2014 to December&nbsp;31, 2015 as a result of share
	repurchases and the completion of the exchange offer, which were partially offset by share issuance under our stock-based awards and certain defined contribution plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net Earnings from Discontinued Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We reported net earnings from discontinued operations of $1.5&nbsp;billion ($5.11 per share) in 2016, $479&nbsp;million ($1.53
	per share) in 2015 and $361&nbsp;million ($1.12 per share) in 2014. Net earnings from discontinued operations in 2016 included a net gain of approximately $1.2&nbsp;billion recognized as a result of the divestiture of the IS&amp;GS business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net Earnings
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We reported net earnings of $5.3&nbsp;billion ($17.49 per share) in 2016, $3.6&nbsp;billion ($11.46 per share) in 2015 and
	$3.6&nbsp;billion ($11.21 per share) in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	36
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Business Segment Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We operate in four business segments: Aeronautics, MFC, RMS and Space Systems. We organize our business segments based on the
	nature of products and services offered. Net sales of our business segments exclude intersegment sales as these activities are eliminated in consolidation. The amounts, discussion and presentation of our business segments as set forth in this Annual
	Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K
</FONT>
	include the results of the acquired Sikorsky business from the November&nbsp;6, 2015 acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating profit of our business segments includes our share of earnings or losses from equity method investees because the
	operating activities of the equity method investees are closely aligned with the operations of our business segments. United Launch Alliance (ULA), which is part of our Space Systems business segment, is one of our largest equity method investees.
	Operating profit of our business segments excludes the FAS/CAS pension adjustment described below; expense for stock-based compensation; the effects of items not considered part of management&#146;s evaluation of segment operating performance, such
	as charges related to goodwill impairments (see &#147;Note 1&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Significant Accounting Policies&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) and significant severance actions (see &#147;Note
	15&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Restructuring Charges&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements); gains or losses from divestitures (see &#147;Note 3&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Acquisitions and Divestitures&#148; included in our Notes to
	Consolidated Financial Statements); the effects of certain legal settlements; corporate costs not allocated to our business segments; and other miscellaneous corporate activities. These items are included in the reconciling item &#147;Unallocated
	items&#148; between operating profit from our business segments and our consolidated operating profit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our business
	segments&#146; results of operations include pension expense only as calculated under U.S. Government Cost Accounting Standards, which we refer to as CAS pension cost. We recover CAS pension cost through the pricing of our products and services on
	U.S. Government contracts and, therefore, the CAS pension cost is recognized in each of our business segments&#146; net sales and cost of sales. Since our consolidated financial statements must present pension expense calculated in accordance with
	FAS requirements under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), which we refer to as FAS pension expense, the FAS/CAS pension adjustment increases or decreases the CAS pension cost recorded in our business segments&#146; results of
	operations to equal the FAS pension expense. As a result, to the extent that CAS pension cost exceeds FAS pension expense, which occurred for 2016, 2015 and 2014, we have a favorable FAS/CAS pension adjustment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The operating results in the following tables exclude businesses included in discontinued operations (see
	&#147;Note&nbsp;3&nbsp;&#150; Acquisitions and Divestitures&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) for all years presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>

	millions):

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following segment discussions also include information relating to backlog for each segment. Backlog was approximately
	$96.2&nbsp;billion, $94.8&nbsp;billion and $74.5&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014. Backlog at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 excludes approximately $4.8&nbsp;billion and $6.0&nbsp;billion of backlog related to our IS&amp;GS
	business, which we divested in 2016. These amounts included both funded backlog (firm orders for which funding has been both authorized and appropriated by the customer) and unfunded backlog (firm orders for which funding has not yet been
	appropriated). Backlog does not include unexercised options or task orders to be issued under indefinite-delivery, indefinite-quantity contracts. Funded backlog was approximately $66.0&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Management evaluates performance on our contracts by focusing on net sales and operating profit and not by type or amount of
	operating expense. Consequently, our discussion of business segment performance focuses on net sales and operating profit, consistent with our approach for managing the business. This approach is consistent throughout the life cycle of our
	contracts, as management assesses the bidding of each contract by focusing on net sales and operating profit and monitors performance on our contracts in a similar manner through their completion.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We regularly provide customers with reports of our costs as the contract progresses. The cost information in the reports is
	accumulated in a manner specified by the requirements of each contract. For example, cost data provided to a customer for
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	a product would typically align to the subcomponents of that product (such as a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	wing-box
</FONT>
	on an aircraft) and for services would align to the type of work
	being performed (such as help-desk support). Our contracts generally are cost-based, which allows for the recovery of costs in the pricing of our products and services. Most of our contracts are bid and negotiated with our customers under
	circumstances in which we are required to disclose our estimated total costs to provide the product or service. This approach for negotiating contracts with our U.S. Government customers generally allows for the recovery of our costs. We also may
	enter into long-term supply contracts for certain materials or components to coincide with the production schedule of certain products and to ensure their availability at known unit prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Many of our contracts span several years and include highly complex technical requirements. At the outset of a contract, we
	identify and monitor risks to the achievement of the technical, schedule and cost aspects of the contract and assess the effects of those risks on our estimates of total costs to complete the contract. The estimates consider the technical
	requirements (e.g., a newly-developed product versus a mature product), the schedule and associated tasks (e.g., the number and type of milestone events) and costs (e.g., material, labor, subcontractor, overhead and the estimated costs to fulfill
	our industrial cooperation agreements required under certain contracts with international customers). The initial profit booking rate of each contract considers risks surrounding the ability to achieve the technical requirements, schedule and costs
	in the initial estimated total costs to complete the contract. Profit booking rates may increase during the performance of the contract if we successfully retire risks surrounding the technical, schedule and cost aspects of the contract which
	decreases the estimated total costs to complete the contract. Conversely, our profit booking rates may decrease if the estimated total costs to complete the contract increase. All of the estimates are subject to change during the performance of the
	contract and may affect the profit booking rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have a number of programs that are designated as classified by the
	U.S. Government which cannot be specifically described. The operating results of these classified programs are included in our consolidated and business segment results and are subjected to the same oversight and internal controls as our other
	programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our net sales are primarily derived from long-term contracts for products and services provided to the U.S.
	Government as well as FMS contracted through the U.S. Government. We account for these contracts, as well as product contracts with
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	Government customers, using the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	percentage-of-completion
</FONT>
</FONT>
	method of accounting, which represent substantially all of our net sales. We derive our remaining net sales from contracts to provide services to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	Government customers, which we account for under the services method of accounting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Under the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	percentage-of-completion
</FONT>
</FONT>
	method of
	accounting, we record sales on contracts based upon our progress towards completion on a particular contract as well as our estimate of the profit to be earned at completion. Cost-reimbursable contracts provide for the payment of allowable costs
	plus a fee. For fixed-priced contracts, net sales and cost of sales are recognized as products are delivered or as costs are incurred. Due to the nature of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	percentage-of-completion
</FONT>
</FONT>
	method of accounting, changes in our cost of sales are typically accompanied by a related change in our net sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Changes in net sales and operating profit generally are expressed in terms of volume. Changes in volume refer to increases or
	decreases in sales or operating profit resulting from varying production activity levels, deliveries or service levels on individual contracts. Volume changes in segment operating profit are typically based on the current profit booking rate for a
	particular contract.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In addition, comparability of our segment sales, operating profit and operating margins may be
	impacted favorably or unfavorably by changes in profit booking rates on our contracts accounted for using the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	percentage-of-completion
</FONT>
</FONT>
	method of accounting. Increases in
	the profit booking rates, typically referred to as risk retirements, usually relate to revisions in the estimated total costs that reflect improved conditions on a particular contract. Conversely, conditions on a particular contract may deteriorate
	resulting in an increase in the estimated total costs to complete and a reduction in the profit booking rate. Increases or decreases in profit booking rates are recognized in the current period and reflect the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	inception-to-date
</FONT>
</FONT>
	effect of such changes. Segment operating profit and margins may also be impacted favorably or unfavorably by other items. Favorable items may include the positive resolution of contractual
	matters, cost recoveries on restructuring charges, insurance recoveries and gains on sales of assets. Unfavorable items may include the adverse resolution of contractual matters; restructuring charges, except for significant severance actions as
	mentioned above which are excluded from segment operating results; reserves for disputes; asset impairments; and losses on sales of assets. Segment operating profit and items such as risk retirements, reductions of profit booking rates or other
	matters are presented net of state income taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have a contract to provide an integrated air and missile defense
	command, control, communications, computers&nbsp;&#150;Integrated Surveillance&nbsp;&amp; Reconnaissance (C4ISR) system to an international customer.&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2015, we revised our estimated costs to complete the program as a
	consequence of performance issues and recorded a reserve of
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	$70&nbsp;million. Since that time, we have continued to experience issues related to customer requirements and the implementation of this contract and have periodically accrued additional
	reserves.&nbsp;Consequently, we are continuing to monitor the&nbsp;scope, estimated costs, and viability of the program and the possibility of additional customer funding.&nbsp;It is possible that we may have to record additional loss reserves in
	future periods, which could be material to our operating results.&nbsp;However, we cannot make an estimate of the total expected costs at this time due to uncertainties inherent in the estimation process.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our consolidated net adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, net
	of state income taxes, increased segment operating profit by approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion, $1.7&nbsp;billion and $1.6&nbsp;billion for 2016, 2015 and 2014. The decrease in our consolidated net adjustments in 2016 compared to 2015 was primarily
	due to a decrease in profit booking rate adjustments at our MFC and Space Systems business segments, partially offset by an increase at our RMS business segment. The increase in our consolidated net adjustments in 2015 compared to 2014 was primarily
	due to an increase in profit booking rate adjustments at our Space Systems and Aeronautics business segments, offset by a decrease in profit booking rate adjustments at our RMS and MFC business segments. The consolidated net adjustments for 2016 are
	inclusive of approximately $530&nbsp;million in unfavorable items, which include reserves for performance matters on an international program at RMS. The consolidated net adjustments for 2015 are inclusive of approximately $550&nbsp;million in
	unfavorable items, which include reserves for performance matters on an international program at RMS and on commercial satellite programs at Space Systems. The consolidated net adjustments for 2014 are inclusive of approximately $535&nbsp;million in
	unfavorable items, which include reserves recorded on certain training and logistics solutions programs at RMS and net warranty reserve adjustments for various programs (including JASSM and GMLRS) at MFC as described in the respective business
	segment&#146;s results of operations below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Aeronautics
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our Aeronautics business segment is engaged in the research, design, development, manufacture, integration, sustainment,
	support and upgrade of advanced military aircraft, including combat and air mobility aircraft, unmanned air vehicles and related technologies. Aeronautics&#146; major programs include the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	Lightning
	II&nbsp;Joint Strike Fighter,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	Hercules,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-16
</FONT>
	Fighting Falcon,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-5M
</FONT>
	Super Galaxy and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-22
</FONT>
	Raptor. Aeronautics&#146; operating results included the following (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Aeronautics&#146; net sales in 2016 increased $2.2&nbsp;billion, or 14%, compared to 2015. The increase was attributable to
	higher net sales of approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program due to increased volume on aircraft production and sustainment activities, partially offset by lower volume on development activities;
	and approximately $290&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program due to increased deliveries (24 aircraft delivered in 2016 compared to 21 in 2015) and increased sustainment activities; and approximately
	$250&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-16
</FONT>
	program primarily due to higher volume on aircraft modernization programs. The increases were partially offset by lower net sales of approximately $55&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-5
</FONT>
	program due to decreased sustainment activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Aeronautics&#146; operating profit
	in 2016 increased $206&nbsp;million, or 12%, compared to 2015. Operating profit increased approximately $195&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program due to increased volume on aircraft production and sustainment
	activities and higher risk retirements; and by approximately $60&nbsp;million for aircraft support and maintenance programs due to higher risk retirements and increased volume. These increases were partially offset by lower operating profit of
	approximately $65&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program due to contract mix and lower risk retirements. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments, were approximately
	$20&nbsp;million higher in 2016 compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Aeronautics&#146; net sales in 2015 increased $650&nbsp;million, or 4%, compared to 2014. The increase was attributable to
	higher net sales of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	production contracts due to increased volume on aircraft production and sustainment activities; and approximately $150&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-5
</FONT>
	program due to increased deliveries (nine aircraft
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	delivered in 2015 compared to seven delivered in 2014). The increases were partially offset by lower net sales of approximately $350&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program due to fewer aircraft deliveries (21 aircraft delivered in 2015, compared to 24 delivered in 2014), lower sustainment activities and aircraft contract mix; approximately $200&nbsp;million due to
	decreased volume and lower risk retirements on various programs; approximately $195&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-16
</FONT>
	program due to fewer deliveries (11 aircraft delivered in 2015, compared to 17 delivered in 2014);
	and approximately $190&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-22&nbsp;program
</FONT>
	as a result of decreased sustainment activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Aeronautics&#146; operating profit in 2015 increased $32&nbsp;million, or 2%, compared to 2014. Operating profit increased by
	approximately $240&nbsp;million for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	production contracts due to increased volume and risk retirements; and approximately $40&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-5
</FONT>
	program due to
	increased risk retirements. These increases were offset by lower operating profit of approximately $90&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-22
</FONT>
	program due to lower risk retirements; approximately $70&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program as a result of the reasons stated above for lower net sales; and approximately $80&nbsp;million due to decreased volume and risk retirements on various programs. Adjustments not related to volume,
	including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately $100&nbsp;million higher in 2015 compared to 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Backlog
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Backlog increased in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to higher orders on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	production and sustainment programs. Backlog increased in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to higher orders on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Trends
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We expect Aeronautics&#146; 2017 net sales to increase in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-double
</FONT>
	digit
	percentage range as compared to 2016 due to increased volume on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program. Operating profit is expected to increase at a slightly lower percentage range, driven by the increased volume on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program, partially offset by contract mix that results in a slight decrease in operating margins between years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Missiles and Fire Control
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our MFC business segment provides air and missile defense systems; tactical missiles and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	air-to-ground
</FONT>
</FONT>
	precision strike weapon systems; logistics; fire control systems; mission operations support, readiness, engineering support and integration services; manned and unmanned ground vehicles; and
	energy management solutions. MFC&#146;s major programs include
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	PAC-3,
</FONT>
	THAAD, Multiple Launch Rocket System, Hellfire, JASSM, Javelin, Apache, Sniper
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	,
	Low Altitude Navigation and Targeting Infrared for Night (LANTIRN
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	) and Special Operations Forces Contractor Logistics Support Services (SOF&nbsp;CLSS). In 2016 we submitted a bid for the
	Special Operations Forces Global Logistics Support Services (SOF&nbsp;GLSS) contract, which is a competitive
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	follow-on
</FONT>
	contract to SOF&nbsp;CLSS. We anticipate an award decision on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	follow-on
</FONT>
	contract in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-2017.
</FONT>
	MFC&#146;s operating results included the following (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	MFC&#146;s net sales in 2016 decreased $162&nbsp;million, or 2%, compared to 2015. The decrease was attributable to lower net
	sales of approximately $205&nbsp;million for air and missile defense programs due to decreased volume (primarily THAAD); and lower net sales of approximately $95&nbsp;million due to lower volume on various programs. These decreases were partially
	offset by a $75&nbsp;million increase for tactical missiles programs due to increased deliveries (primarily Hellfire); and approximately $70&nbsp;million for fire control programs due to increased volume (SOF CLSS).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	MFC&#146;s operating profit in 2016 decreased $264&nbsp;million, or 21%, compared to 2015. Operating profit decreased
	approximately $145&nbsp;million for air and missile defense programs due to lower risk retirements
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(PAC-3
</FONT>
	and THAAD) and a reserve for a contractual matter; approximately $45&nbsp;million for tactical missiles
	programs due to lower risk retirements (Javelin); and approximately $45&nbsp;million for fire control programs due to lower risk retirements (Apache) and program mix. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments
	and reserves, were about $225&nbsp;million lower in 2016 compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	MFC&#146;s net sales in 2015 decreased $322&nbsp;million, or 5%, compared to the same period in 2014. The decrease was
	attributable to lower net sales of approximately $345&nbsp;million for air and missile defense programs due to fewer deliveries (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	PAC-3)
</FONT>
	and lower volume (primarily THAAD); and approximately
	$85&nbsp;million for tactical missile programs due to fewer deliveries (primarily Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System (GMLRS)) and Joint
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Air-to-Surface
</FONT>
</FONT>
	Standoff
	Missile, partially offset by increased deliveries for Hellfire. These decreases were partially offset by higher net sales of approximately $55&nbsp;million for energy solutions programs due to increased volume.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	MFC&#146;s operating profit in 2015 decreased $62&nbsp;million, or 5%, compared to 2014. The decrease was attributable to
	lower operating profit of approximately $100&nbsp;million for fire control programs due primarily to lower risk retirements (primarily LANTIRN and SNIPER); and approximately $65&nbsp;million for tactical missile programs due to lower risk
	retirements (primarily Hellfire and GMLRS) and fewer deliveries. These decreases were partially offset by higher operating profit of approximately $75&nbsp;million for air and missile defense programs due to increased risk retirements (primarily
	THAAD). Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately $60&nbsp;million lower in 2015 compared to 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Backlog
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Backlog
	decreased in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to lower orders on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	PAC-3,
</FONT>
	Hellfire, and JASSM. Backlog increased in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to higher orders on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	PAC-3,
</FONT>
	LANTIRN/Sniper and certain tactical missile programs, partially offset by lower orders on THAAD.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Trends
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We expect MFC&#146;s net sales to increase in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-single
</FONT>
	digit percentage
	range in 2017 as compared to 2016 driven primarily by our air and missile defense programs. Operating profit is expected to be flat or increase slightly. Accordingly, operating profit margin is expected to decline from 2016 levels as a result of
	contract mix and fewer risk retirements in 2017 compared to 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Rotary and Mission Systems
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As previously described, on November&nbsp;6, 2015, we acquired Sikorsky and aligned the Sikorsky business under our RMS
	business segment. The 2015 results of the acquired Sikorsky business have been included in our financial results from the November&nbsp;6, 2015 acquisition date through December&nbsp;31, 2015. As a result, our consolidated operating results and RMS
	business segment operating results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 do not reflect a full year of Sikorsky operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our RMS business segment provides design, manufacture, service and support for a variety of military and civil helicopters,
	ship and submarine mission and combat systems; mission systems and sensors for rotary and fixed-wing aircraft; sea and land-based missile defense systems; radar systems; the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS); simulation and training services; and unmanned
	systems and technologies. In addition, RMS supports the needs of government customers in cybersecurity and delivers communication and command and control capabilities through complex mission solutions for defense applications. RMS&#146; major
	programs include Black Hawk and Seahawk helicopters, Aegis Combat System (Aegis), LCS, Space Fence, Advanced Hawkeye Radar System,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	TPQ-53
</FONT>
	Radar System,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	CH-53K
</FONT>
	development helicopter, and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	VH-92A
</FONT>
	helicopter program. RMS&#146; operating results included the following (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	RMS&#146; net sales in 2016 increased $4.4&nbsp;billion, or 48%, compared to 2015. The increase was primarily attributable to
	higher net sales of approximately $4.6&nbsp;billion from Sikorsky, which was acquired on November&nbsp;6, 2015. Net sales for 2015 include Sikorsky&#146;s results subsequent to the acquisition date, net of certain revenue adjustments required to
	account for the acquisition of this business. This increase was partially offset by lower net sales of approximately $70&nbsp;million for training
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	and logistics programs due to the divestiture of our LMCFT business, which reported sales through the May&nbsp;2, 2016 divestiture date; and approximately $65&nbsp;million for ship and aviation
	systems programs due to decreased volume on various programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	RMS&#146; operating profit in 2016 increased
	$62&nbsp;million, or 7%, compared to 2015. Operating profit increased approximately $85&nbsp;million for training and logistics programs due primarily to the divestiture of our LMCFT business which generated operating losses through its May&nbsp;2,
	2016 divestiture date; about $60&nbsp;million for our integrated warfare systems and sensors programs due to investments made in connection with a next generation radar technology program awarded during 2015; and approximately $55&nbsp;million for
	undersea systems programs due primarily to higher reserves for performance matters on an international program in 2015. These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $70&nbsp;million as a result of a higher operating loss from Sikorsky,
	inclusive of the unfavorable impacts of intangible asset amortization and other adjustments required to account for the acquisition of this business; about $30&nbsp;million for ship and aviation systems programs due primarily to performance on
	various programs; and about $25&nbsp;million for other matters. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and reserves, were about $155&nbsp;million higher in 2016 compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	RMS&#146; net sales in 2015 increased $359&nbsp;million, or 4%, compared to 2014. The increase was attributable to net sales
	of approximately $400&nbsp;million from Sikorsky, net of adjustments required to account for the acquisition of this business in the fourth quarter of 2015; and approximately $220&nbsp;million for integrated warfare systems and sensors programs,
	primarily due to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	ramp-up
</FONT>
	of recently awarded programs (Space Fence). These increases were partially offset by lower net sales of approximately $150&nbsp;million for undersea systems programs due to
	decreased volume as a result of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-theater
</FONT>
	force reductions (primarily Persistent Threat Detection System); and approximately $105&nbsp;million for ship and aviation systems programs primarily due to decreased
	volume (Merlin Capability Sustainment Program).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	RMS&#146; operating profit in 2015 decreased $92&nbsp;million, or 10%,
	compared to 2014. Operating profit decreased by approximately $75&nbsp;million due to performance matters on an international program; approximately $45&nbsp;million for Sikorsky due primarily to intangible amortization and adjustments required to
	account for the acquisition of this business in the fourth quarter of 2015; and approximately $15&nbsp;million for integrated warfare systems and sensors programs, primarily due to investments made in connection with a recently awarded next
	generation radar technology program, partially offset by higher risk retirements (including Halifax Class&nbsp;Modernization). These decreases were partially offset by approximately $20&nbsp;million in increased operating profit for training and
	logistics services programs, primarily due to reserves recorded on certain programs in 2014 that were not repeated in 2015. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately
	$100&nbsp;million lower in 2015 compared to 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Backlog
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Backlog decreased in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to sales being recognized on several multi-year programs (primarily
	in Sikorsky) related to prior year awards. Backlog increased in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to the addition of Sikorsky&#146;s backlog, as well as higher orders on new program starts (such as Australian Defence Force Pilot Training System).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Trends
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We expect
	RMS&#146; 2017 net sales to increase in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-single
</FONT>
	digit percentage range compared to 2016. Operating profit is expected to increase in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-double-digit
</FONT>
	percentage range due to a reduction in certain purchase accounting adjustments that were attributable to the Sikorsky acquisition, resulting in higher operating profit margins between years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Space Systems
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our Space Systems business segment is engaged in the research and development, design, engineering and production of
	satellites, strategic and defensive missile systems and space transportation systems. Space Systems provides network-enabled situational awareness and integrates complex space and ground-based global systems to help our customers gather, analyze,
	and securely distribute critical intelligence data. Space Systems is also responsible for various classified systems and services in support of vital national security systems. Space Systems&#146; major programs include the Trident II D5 Fleet
	Ballistic Missile (FBM), Orion, Space Based Infrared System (SBIRS), AEHF,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	GPS-III,
</FONT>
	Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	R-Series
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(GOES-R),
</FONT>
	and The Mobile User Objective System (MUOS). Operating profit for our Space Systems business
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	43
</P>

	following (in millions):
