<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Space Systems&#146; net sales in 2016 increased $304&nbsp;million, or 3%, compared to 2015. The increase was attributable to
	net sales of approximately $410&nbsp;million from AWE following the consolidation of this business in the third quarter of 2016; and approximately $150&nbsp;million for commercial space transportation programs due to increased launch-related
	activities; and approximately $70&nbsp;million of higher net sales for various programs (primarily Fleet Ballistic Missiles) due to increased volume. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in net sales of approximately $340&nbsp;million
	for government satellite programs due to decreased volume (primarily SBIRS and MUOS) and the wind-down or completion of mission solutions programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Space Systems&#146; operating profit in 2016 increased $118&nbsp;million, or 10%, compared to 2015. The increase was primarily
	attributable to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of approximately $127&nbsp;million related to the consolidation of AWE; and approximately $80&nbsp;million of increased equity
	earnings from joint ventures (primarily ULA). These increases were partially offset by a decrease of approximately $105&nbsp;million for government satellite programs due to lower risk retirements (primarily SBIRS, MUOS and mission solutions
	programs) and decreased volume. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments, were approximately $185&nbsp;million lower in 2016 compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Space Systems&#146; net sales in 2015 decreased $97&nbsp;million, or 1%, compared to 2014. The decrease was attributable to
	approximately $335&nbsp;million lower net sales for government satellite programs due to decreased volume (primarily AEHF) and the wind-down or completion of mission solutions programs; and approximately $55&nbsp;million for strategic missile and
	defense systems due to lower volume. These decreases were partially offset by higher net sales of approximately $235&nbsp;million for businesses acquired in 2014; and approximately $75&nbsp;million for the Orion program due to increased volume.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Space Systems&#146; operating profit in 2015 decreased $16&nbsp;million, or 1%, compared to 2014. Operating profit increased
	approximately $85&nbsp;million for government satellite programs due primarily to increased risk retirements. This increase was offset by lower operating profit of approximately $65&nbsp;million for commercial satellite programs due to performance
	matters on certain programs; and approximately $35&nbsp;million due to decreased equity earnings in joint ventures. Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately
	$105&nbsp;million higher in 2015 compared to 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Equity earnings
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Total equity earnings recognized by Space Systems (primarily ULA) represented approximately $325&nbsp;million,
	$245&nbsp;million and $280&nbsp;million, or 25%, 21% and 24% of this business segment&#146;s operating profit during 2016, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Backlog
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Backlog increased in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to the addition of AWE&#146;s backlog. Backlog decreased in
	2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to lower orders for government satellite programs and the Orion program and higher sales on the Orion program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Trends
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We expect Space
	Systems&#146; 2017 net sales to decrease in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-single
</FONT>
	digit percentage range as compared to 2016, driven by program lifecycles on government satellite programs, partially offset by the recognition of AWE
	net sales for a full year in 2017 versus a partial year in 2016 following the consolidation of AWE in the third quarter of 2016. Operating profit
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	44
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	is expected to decline in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-
</FONT>
	to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-double
</FONT>
	digit percentage range, primarily driven by sales volume, the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	AWE
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	gain in 2016, amortization of the AWE intangible assets in 2017, and lower equity earnings in 2017 compared to 2016. As a result operating profit margin
	is expected to decline from 2016 levels.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity and Cash Flows
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have a balanced cash deployment strategy to enhance stockholder value and position ourselves to take advantage of new
	business opportunities when they arise. Consistent with that strategy, we have continued to invest in our business, including capital expenditures, independent research and development and made selective business acquisitions, while returning cash
	to stockholders through dividends and share repurchases, and managing our debt levels, maturities and interest rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We
	have generated strong operating cash flows, which have been the primary source of funding for our operations, capital expenditures, debt service and repayments, dividends, share repurchases and postretirement benefit plan contributions. Our strong
	operating cash flows enabled our Board of Directors to approve two key cash deployment initiatives in September 2016. First, we increased our fourth quarter dividend rate by 10% to $1.82 per share. Second, the Board of Directors approved a
	$2.0&nbsp;billion increase to our share repurchase program. Inclusive of this increase, the total remaining authorization for future common share repurchases under our program was $3.5&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016, we received a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-free
</FONT>
	special cash payment of approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion as a result of the divestiture of the IS&amp;GS business in the third quarter of 2016. We used the proceeds to repay $500&nbsp;million of long-term notes at their scheduled maturity and paid
	$484&nbsp;million in dividends with a portion of this cash. The remainder was used for share repurchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have
	accessed the capital markets opportunistically as we did in February 2015 when we issued $2.25&nbsp;billion of long-term debt and as needed as we did in November 2015 when we issued $7.0&nbsp;billion of long-term debt in connection with our
	acquisition of Sikorsky. We also used a combination of short-term debt financing, commercial paper and available cash to fund the Sikorsky acquisition, as discussed below in &#147;Capital Structure, Resources and Other&#148; and &#147;Note
	10&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Debt&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. We expect our cash from operations will continue to be sufficient to support our operations and anticipated capital expenditures for the foreseeable future.
	However, we expect to continue to issue commercial paper backed by our revolving credit facility to manage the timing of our cash flows. As described in the &#147;Capital Structure, Resources and Other&#148; section below, we have financing
	resources available to fund potential cash outflows that are less predictable or more discretionary, should they occur. We also have access to credit markets, if needed, for liquidity or general corporate purposes, including, but not limited to, our
	revolving credit facility or the ability to issue commercial paper, and letters of credit to support customer advance payments and for other trade finance purposes such as guaranteeing our performance on particular contracts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash received from customers, either from the payment of invoices for work performed or for advances in excess of costs
	incurred, is our primary source of cash. We generally do not begin work on contracts until funding is appropriated by the customer. However, we may determine to fund customer programs ourselves pending government appropriations and are doing so with
	increased frequency. If we incur costs in excess of funds obligated on the contract, we may be at risk for reimbursement of the excess costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Billing timetables and payment terms on our contracts vary based on a number of factors, including the contract type. We
	generally bill and collect cash more frequently under cost-reimbursable and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	time-and-materials
</FONT>
</FONT>
	contracts, which together represent approximately half of the sales we
	recorded in 2016, as we are authorized to bill as the costs are incurred or work is performed. A number of our fixed-price contracts may provide for performance-based payments, which allow us to bill and collect cash as we perform on the contract.
	The amount of performance-based payments and the related milestones are encompassed in the negotiation of each contract. The timing of such payments may differ from our incurrence of costs related to our contract performance, thereby affecting our
	cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The U.S. Government has indicated that it would consider progress payments as the baseline for negotiating
	payment terms on fixed-price contracts, rather than performance-based payments. In contrast to negotiated performance-based payment terms, progress payment provisions correspond to a percentage of the amount of costs incurred during the performance
	of the contract. While the total amount of cash collected on a contract is the same, performance-based payments have had a more favorable impact on the timing of our cash flows. In addition, our cash flows may be affected if the U.S. Government
	decides to withhold payments on our billings. While the impact of withholding payments delays the receipt of cash, the cumulative amount of cash collected during the life of the contract will not vary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	45
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The majority of our capital expenditures for 2016 and those planned for 2017 are
	for equipment, facilities infrastructure and information technology. Expenditures for equipment and facilities infrastructure are generally incurred to support new and existing programs across all of our business segments. For example, we have
	projects underway in our Aeronautics business segment for facilities and equipment to support higher production of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	combat aircraft, and we have projects underway to modernize certain of our
	facilities. We also incur capital expenditures for information technology to support programs and general enterprise information technology infrastructure, inclusive of costs for the development or purchase of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	internal-use
</FONT>
	software.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table provides a summary of our cash flow
	information followed by a discussion of the key elements (in&nbsp;millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

</P>

</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net cash provided by operating activities increased $88&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due to a reduction in
	cash paid for income taxes, partially offset by an increase in cash paid for interest expense and an increase in cash used for working capital. The $196&nbsp;million increase in cash flows used for working capital (defined as receivables and
	inventories less accounts payable and customer advances and amounts in excess of costs incurred) was attributable to timing of cash receipts for receivables (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	program), partially offset by timing
	of production and billing cycles affecting customer advances and progress payments applied to inventories (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program). See &#147;Critical Accounting Policies&nbsp;&#150;Postretirement Benefit
	Plans&#148; (under the caption &#147;Funding Considerations&#148;) for discussion of future postretirement benefit plan funding. We made net income tax payments of $1.3&nbsp;billion and $1.8&nbsp;billion during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016
	and 2015, respectively. We made interest payments of approximately $600&nbsp;million and approximately $375&nbsp;million during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We may determine to fund customer programs ourselves pending government appropriations. If we incur costs in excess of funds
	obligated on a contract, we are at risk for reimbursement of the excess costs. In 2014 and 2015, we received customer authorization and initial funding to begin producing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	aircraft to be acquired under
	LRIP 9 and 10 contracts, respectively. As a result of recent funding by the U.S. Government, our potential cash exposure and termination liability were not material at December&nbsp;31, 2016. However, it may become material if government
	appropriations are delayed as was the case in the second and third quarters of 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net cash provided by operating activities increased $1.2&nbsp;billion in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to lower pension
	contributions, partially offset by decreases in working capital and higher tax payments. The $1.8&nbsp;billion increase in cash flows related to other, net in the table above is primarily because we made no contributions to our heritage qualified
	defined benefit pension trust in 2015 compared to $2.0&nbsp;billion in 2014. We made $5.0&nbsp;million in contributions to our new Sikorsky bargained qualified defined benefit pension plan in 2015. The increase in cash flows related to other, net
	was offset by higher federal and foreign income tax payments, net of refunds received, of approximately $210&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to 2014 due primarily to the absence of refunds received in 2015 (prior year&#146;s tax refunds were
	attributable to timing of discretionary pension contributions made during the fourth quarter of the respective previous years). The $474&nbsp;million decrease in cash flows related to working capital (defined as receivables and inventories less
	accounts payable
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	46
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	and customer advances and amounts in excess of costs incurred) was attributable to an increase in receivables due to timing of customer collections (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	F-35
</FONT>
	contracts) as well as timing of production and billing cycles affecting customer advances and progress payments applied to inventories (primarily
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	C-130
</FONT>
	program).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Investing Activities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net cash used for investing activities decreased $8.7&nbsp;billion in 2016 compared to the prior year, primarily due to
	$9.0&nbsp;billion of cash used for acquisition activities in 2015 that did not recur in 2016. Net cash used for investing activities increased $8.0&nbsp;billion in 2015 compared to 2014, primarily due to cash used for acquisition activities.
	Acquisition activities include both the acquisition of businesses and investments in affiliates. We had no acquisitions in 2016. In 2015 we paid $9.0&nbsp;billion for the Sikorsky acquisition, net of cash acquired. In 2014, we paid $898&nbsp;million
	for acquisition activities, primarily related to the acquisitions of Zeta, Systems Made Simple, and Industrial Defender (see &#147;Note 3&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Acquisitions and Divestitures&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial
	Statements).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Capital expenditures amounted to $1.1&nbsp;billion in 2016, $939&nbsp;million in 2015 and $845&nbsp;million
	in 2014. The majority of our capital expenditures were for equipment and facilities infrastructure that generally are incurred to support new and existing programs across all of our business segments. We also incur capital expenditures for
	information technology to support programs and general enterprise information technology infrastructure, inclusive of costs for the development or purchase of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	internal-use-software.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Additionally, in
	2015, we received cash proceeds of approximately $165&nbsp;million related to three properties sold in California.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Financing
	Activities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net cash used for financing activities increased $7.7&nbsp;billion in 2016 compared to 2015 primarily due
	to proceeds from the issuance of long-term debt in 2015 which did not recur in 2016, the repayments of long-term debt in 2016, and higher dividend payments, partially offset by the proceeds from the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	special cash payment of $1.8&nbsp;billion from the divestiture of the IS&amp;GS business and a reduction in cash used for repurchases of common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net cash provided by financing activities increased $7.6&nbsp;billion in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to proceeds from
	new debt issuances, partially offset by increased repurchases of common stock and higher dividends paid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In May 2016, we
	repaid $452&nbsp;million of long-term notes with a fixed interest rate of 7.65% according to their scheduled maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In September 2016, we repaid $500&nbsp;million of long-term notes with a fixed interest rate of 2.13% according to their
	scheduled maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In February 2015, we received net proceeds of $2.21&nbsp;billion for the issuance of
	$2.25&nbsp;billion of fixed interest-rate long-term notes. In November 2015, we borrowed $7.0&nbsp;billion of fixed interest-rate long-term notes and received net proceeds of $6.9&nbsp;billion (the November 2015 Notes). These proceeds were used to
	repay $6.0&nbsp;billion of outstanding borrowings under a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	364-day
</FONT>
	revolving credit facility that was used to finance a portion of the purchase price for the Sikorsky acquisition. Additionally, in the fourth
	quarter of 2015, to partially finance the Sikorsky acquisition we borrowed and repaid approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion under our commercial paper program. See the &#147;Capital Structure, Resources and Other&#148; discussion below and &#147;Note
	10&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Debt&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for more information about our debt financing activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We paid dividends totaling $2.0&nbsp;billion ($6.77 per share) in 2016, $1.9&nbsp;billion ($6.15 per share) in 2015 and
	$1.8&nbsp;billion ($5.49 per share) in 2014. We have increased our quarterly dividend rate in each of the last three years, including a 10% increase in the quarterly dividend rate in the fourth quarter of 2016. We declared quarterly dividends of
	$1.65 per share during each of the first three quarters of 2016 and $1.82 per share during the fourth quarter of 2016; $1.50 per share during each of the first three quarters of 2015 and $1.65 per share during the fourth quarter of 2015; and $1.33
	per share during each of the first three quarters of 2014 and $1.50 per share during the fourth quarter of 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We paid
	$2.1&nbsp;billion, $3.1&nbsp;billion and $1.9&nbsp;billion to repurchase 8.9&nbsp;million, 15.2&nbsp;million and 11.5&nbsp;million shares of our common stock during 2016, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	47
</P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash received from the issuance of our common stock in connection with employee
	stock option exercises during 2016, 2015 and 2014 totaled $106&nbsp;million, $174&nbsp;million and $308&nbsp;million. The exercises resulted in the issuance of 1.2&nbsp;million, 2.2&nbsp;million and 3.7&nbsp;million shares of our common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
	Capital Structure, Resources and Other
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, we held cash and cash equivalents of $1.8&nbsp;billion. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately
	$400&nbsp;million of our cash and cash equivalents was held outside of the U.S. by foreign subsidiaries. Although those balances are generally available to fund ordinary business operations without legal or other restrictions, a significant portion
	is not immediately available to fund U.S. operations unless repatriated. Our intention is to permanently reinvest earnings from our foreign subsidiaries. While we do not intend to do so, if this cash had been repatriated at the end of 2016, we
	estimate that about $64&nbsp;million of U.S. federal income tax would have been due after considering foreign tax credits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our outstanding debt, net of unamortized discounts and issuance costs, amounted to $14.3&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31,
	2016 and mainly is in the form of publicly-issued notes that bear interest at fixed rates. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we were in compliance with all covenants contained in our debt and credit agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We actively seek to finance our business in a manner that preserves financial flexibility while minimizing borrowing costs to
	the extent practicable. We review changes in financial market and economic conditions to manage the types, amounts and maturities of our indebtedness. We may at times refinance existing indebtedness, vary our mix of variable-rate and fixed-rate debt
	or seek alternative financing sources for our cash and operational needs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On occasion, customers may seek financing for
	the purchase of our products. In connection with these transactions, we may enter into arrangements along with our customers with unrelated third&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;party financial institutions to facilitate the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recourse
</FONT>
	sale of customer receivables. For accounting purposes, these transactions are treated as a sale of receivables and the sale proceeds from the banks are reflected in our operating cash flows on the
	consolidated statements of cash flows. During 2016, there was no significant activity related to sales of customer receivables.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Revolving Credit Facilities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On October&nbsp;9, 2015, we entered into a new $2.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility (the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility) with various banks. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility, was amended in October 2016 to extend its expiration date by one year from October&nbsp;9, 2020 to
	October&nbsp;9, 2021. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility is available for general corporate purposes. The undrawn portion of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility is also available to serve as a backup
	facility for the issuance of commercial paper. We may request and the banks may grant, at their discretion, an increase to the credit facility up to an additional $500&nbsp;million. There were no borrowings outstanding under the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility as of and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Borrowings under
	the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility are unsecured and bear interest at rates based, at our option, on a Eurodollar Rate or a Base Rate, as defined in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility&#146;s
	agreement. Each bank&#146;s obligation to make loans under the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility is subject to, among other things, our compliance with various representations, warranties and covenants, including covenants
	limiting our ability and certain of our subsidiaries&#146; ability to encumber assets and a covenant not to exceed a maximum leverage ratio, as defined in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	Facility agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Long-Term Debt
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	See &#147;Note 10&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Debt&#148; included in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for information about
	our long-term debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have an effective shelf registration statement on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	S-3
</FONT>
	on file with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to provide for the issuance of an indeterminate amount of debt securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Commercial Paper
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have agreements in place with financial institutions to provide for the issuance of commercial paper backed by our
	$2.5&nbsp;billion credit facility. During 2016, we borrowed and fully repaid amounts under our commercial paper programs. There were no commercial paper borrowings outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. However, we expect to continue to issue
	commercial paper backed by our credit facility to manage the timing of our cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	48
</P>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Total Equity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our total equity was $1.6&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of $1.5&nbsp;billion from December&nbsp;31, 2015.
	The decrease was primarily due to the 9.4&nbsp;million common shares tendered and retired in connection with the divestiture of our IS&amp;GS business for $2.5&nbsp;billion; the repurchase of 8.9&nbsp;million common shares for $2.1&nbsp;billion; and
	dividends declared of $2.0&nbsp;billion during the year. These decreases were partially offset by net earnings of $5.3&nbsp;billion and employee stock activity of $399&nbsp;million (including the impacts of stock option exercises, ESOP activity and
	stock-based compensation).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As we repurchase our common shares, we reduce common stock for the $1 of par value of the
	shares repurchased, with the excess purchase price over par value recorded as a reduction of additional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	paid-in
</FONT>
	capital. Due to the volume of repurchases made under our share repurchase program, additional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	paid-in
</FONT>
	capital was reduced to zero, with the remainder of the excess purchase price over par value of $1.7&nbsp;billion recorded as a reduction of retained earnings in 2016.
</P>

	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had contractual commitments to repay debt, make payments under operating leases, settle
	obligations related to agreements to purchase goods and services and settle tax and other liabilities. Capital lease obligations were not material. Payments due under these obligations and commitments are as follows (in millions):
</P>

</EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:4PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:9PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	(a)
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:9PT">
	Long-term debt includes scheduled principal payments only and excludes approximately $13&nbsp;million of debt
	issued by a consolidated joint venture, for which the debt is not guaranteed by us.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Amounts related to
	other liabilities represent the contractual obligations for certain long-term liabilities recorded as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. Such amounts mainly include expected payments under
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-qualified
</FONT>
	pension plans,
	environmental liabilities and deferred compensation plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Purchase obligations related to operating activities include
	agreements and contracts that give the supplier recourse to us for cancellation or nonperformance under the contract or contain terms that would subject us to liquidated damages. Such agreements and contracts may, for example, be related to direct
	materials, obligations to subcontractors and outsourcing arrangements. Total purchase obligations for operating activities in the preceding table include approximately $33&nbsp;billion related to contractual commitments entered into as a result of
	contracts we have with our U.S. Government customers. The U.S. Government generally would be required to pay us for any costs we incur relative to these commitments if they were to terminate the related contracts &#147;for convenience&#148; under
	the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR), subject to available funding. This also would be true in cases where we perform subcontract work for a prime contractor under a U.S. Government contract. The termination for convenience language also may be
	included in contracts with foreign, state and local governments. We also have contracts with customers that do not include termination for convenience provisions, including contracts with commercial customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Purchase obligations in the preceding table for capital expenditures generally include facilities infrastructure, equipment
	and information technology.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We also may enter into industrial cooperation agreements, sometimes referred to as offset
	agreements, as a condition to obtaining orders for our products and services from certain customers in foreign countries. These agreements are designed to enhance the social and economic environment of the foreign country by requiring the contractor
	to promote investment in the country. Offset agreements may be satisfied through activities that do not require us to use cash, including transferring technology, providing manufacturing and other consulting support to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-country
</FONT>
	projects and the purchase by third parties
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	49
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D290249D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	(e.g.
<I>
	,
</I>
	our vendors) of supplies from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-country
</FONT>
	vendors. These agreements also may be satisfied through our use of cash for such activities as
	purchasing supplies from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-country
</FONT>
	vendors, providing financial support for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-country
</FONT>
	projects, establishment of ventures with local companies and building or leasing
	facilities for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-country
</FONT>
	operations. We typically do not commit to offset agreements until orders for our products or services are definitive. The amounts ultimately applied against our offset agreements are
	based on negotiations with the customer and typically require cash outlays that represent only a fraction of the original amount in the offset agreement. Satisfaction of our offset obligations are included in the estimates of our total costs to
	complete the contract and may impact our sales, profitability and cash flows. Our ability to recover investments on our consolidated balance sheet that we make to satisfy offset obligations is generally dependent upon the successful operation of
	ventures that we do not control and may involve products and services that are dissimilar to our business activities. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the notional value of remaining obligations under our outstanding offset agreements totaled
	approximately $15&nbsp;billion, which primarily relate to our Aeronautics, MFC and RMS business segments, most of which extend through 2044. To the extent we have entered into purchase obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2016 that also satisfy offset
	agreements, those amounts are included in the preceding table. Offset programs usually extend over several years and may provide for penalties, estimated at approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, in the event we fail to perform
	in accordance with offset requirements. While historically we have not been required to pay material penalties, resolution of offset requirements are often the result of negotiations and subjective judgments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with our 50% ownership interest of ULA, we and The Boeing Company (Boeing) are required to provide ULA an
	additional capital contribution if ULA is unable to make required payments under its inventory supply agreement with Boeing. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, ULA&#146;s total remaining obligation to Boeing under the inventory supply agreement was
	$120&nbsp;million. The parties have agreed to defer the remaining payment obligation as it is more than offset by other commitments to ULA. Accordingly, we do not expect to be required to make a capital contribution to ULA under this agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In addition, both we and Boeing have cross-indemnified each other for guarantees by us and Boeing of the performance and
	financial obligations of ULA under certain launch service contracts. We believe ULA will be able to fully perform its obligations, as it has done through December&nbsp;31, 2016, and that it will not be necessary to make payments under the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	cross-indemnities or guarantees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:3%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We have entered into standby letters of credit, surety bonds and third-party guarantees with financial institutions and other
	third parties primarily relating to advances received from customers and the guarantee of future performance on certain contracts. Letters of credit and surety bonds generally are available for draw down in the event we do not perform. In some
	cases, we may guarantee the contractual performance of third parties such as venture partners. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had the following outstanding letters of credit, surety bonds and third-party guarantees (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
